liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Melbourne has jumped up the ranks to become the third Most Liveable City in the world. The latest global liveability index puts Melbourne above Sydney, which is at number four, mostly due to culture and environment. Last year, Melbourne came in at number 10. Vienna reigns supreme though thanks to its "stability, good culture and entertainment, reliable infrastructure, and exemplary education and health service." Here's how the top 10 positions shake out: Vienna, Austria Copenhagen, Denmark Melbourne, Australia Sydney, Australia Vancouver, Canada Zurich, Switzerland Calgary, Canada (tied with Geneva) Geneva, Switzerland (tied with Calgary) Toronto, Canada Osaka, Japan (tied with Auckland) Auckland, New Zealand (tied with Osaka) Alright. What do we think? Does Melbourne really deserve third spot? And over Sydney? What about Brisbane? First Taylor Swift snubs us and now this .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Melbourne jumps ranks to become third most liveable city

props.alt: A wide shot of the Melbourne river.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: CEO and Executive Director of San Leon Energy PLC Oisin Fanning, who has been on the OceanGate twice, says there may be more oxygen left on the submersible than expected. He told RN Breakfast the passengers on board were professionals, and they would be rationing their oxygen. "They will be utilising their oxygen very sparingly," he said. "They will not be fast breathing, they will not be panicking." He said they have chemicals and blankets on board which help keep the carbon dioxide out of the air. "So I think that window of 20 hours that people keep talking about will not apply to these people. I think they could easily get another 24 hours out of this."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Submersible could have more oxygen left

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: NSW Police have charged two men and seized luxury cars and other items in an investigation into an alleged cryptocurrency scam. Financial Crime Squad detectives arrested a 39-year-old man on Friday on Sydney's Northern Beaches, and allege he defrauded two companies of $5.5 million dollars. They searched a home and warehouse in Cromer, where they seized six luxury and classic cars, as well as 11 motorcycles, seven luxury watches, nun chucks, cryptocurrency wallets and documentation relevant to their investigation. Yesterday police arrested a 67-year-old man, alleging he authorised the the funds and tried to help the 39-year-old avoid police by disposing of a $600,000 dollar Ferrari. Both men remain before the courts.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Two arrested in alleged $5.5 million cryptocurrency scam

props.alt: Police officers in a garage with five visible cars and several motorbikes.
